comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Photographer R. G. Sands of Albany, W.A. ?

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] That's our man, there are some catalogue records (no images yet) for some other panoramas by Sands in the collection of the State Library of Western Australia. Would be interesting to compare!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Not too sure with this GoogleMapsStreetView - goo.gl/maps/UirRQ ?? Perhaps someone else can find a better one. Trouble is the more I look, the more I want to go there - King George Sound looks magical.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Read All About It! - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/83526996 And (drumroll ...) vividly described by A. B. "Banjo" Paterson in the SMH 8/12/1914 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/15546804

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Ha! Much better GoogleMapsStreetView, closer to Albany, see the islands in the middle - goo.gl/maps/7a2fL

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Ah ABP what a story teller: 'The only sign of life is the column of smoke pouring from each funnel, and this alone it is that tells us that Australia's greatest maritime venture is about to put out to sea.... A vague electric restlessness is in the air...' I know that there are plans in the pipeline for centenary activities surrouding the events depicted here - perhaps you could make your visit to King George Sound then!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] I hope the centenary activities are not as secret as the original event. From the Read All About It! link above - " ... To show the secrecy which prevailed during the stay of the fleet here, people residing only a few miles from the town [Albany] did not know of the presence of the vessels in port." And the newspaper reports were published weeks later.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] No secret at all by the looks of things! After Gallipoli, Albany will apparently be the biggest 'pilgrimage' site re the WW1 centenary. Better get in quick ;)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
